In this case, when a cmdlet error-out, the full error message seems to be partially suppressed. 
This is not happening in Windows PowerShell.

And, it's forcing the do extra steps (run $error.exception) to display more information about the error.

# Steps to reproduce
Run the command Get-ChildItem to list files from a non-existing drive.
```powershell
 Get-ChildItem j:\*.txt

```

# Expected behavior
To show the full error message.
```none
PS [19] > ## - Output sample from Windows PowerShell:
PS [20] > Get-ChildItem j:\*.txt
Get-ChildItem : Cannot find drive. A drive with the name 'j' does not exist.
At line:1 char:1
+ Get-ChildItem j:\*.txt
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (j:String) [Get-ChildItem], DriveNotFoundException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : DriveNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetChildItemCommand

P
```

# Actual behavior
It's forcing me to use additional step, $error.exception to get error message.
```none
PS [22] > Get-ChildItem j:\*.txt
Get-ChildItem :
PS [24] >
PS [25] > $error.exception
Cannot find drive. A drive with the name 'j' does not exist.
```

# Environment data

```none
PS [7] > $PSVersionTable

PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
